parameters.source_text:
©. Case 10-6
: Sterilization of an Economically Deprived Woman
Tilly Johnson lived with her 2-year-old daughter in a small town in a south-
eastern state. She discovered that she was pregnant for the fourth time. At
24 years of age she was distressed. She had had three previous pregnan-
cies. In addition to her daughter, she had a son when she had been married
briefly to a man no longer in her life. The Department of Child Protection
took custody of the baby. Last year she had had an abortion of a pregnancy
that resulted from a brief relationship with another man. This time she de-
cided she would keep the baby.
She was being seen at the clinic at the local hospital designed to pro-
vide prenatal care for women who might otherwise not receive any medical
care prior to childbirth. She was being seen by Dr. Andrew Lacey. He had
first seen her when she was six months pregnant. He realized she was un-
happy with the pregnancy. He counseled her about the pregnancy and,
during the visit at the seventh month, asked her to consider having her tubes
tied as part of the delivery. Dr. Lacey was also a Southern Baptist. He had
some concerns about sterilization but believed it was appropriate for women
who are not in a position to provide long-term support for their children.
Ms. Johnson was interested in the possibility of sterilization but
seemed ambivalent. She knew that two children would be all she could
handle. Her Baptist upbringing did not explicitly oppose sterilization, but
her church leaders had emphasized the importance of motherhood and ex-
pressed the importance of avoiding permanently foreclosing further preg-
nancies. She hoped that some day the right man would come into her life
and she could be part of what she considered a normal family. On the other
hand, she knew it would be economically and socially bad for her to have
more children for the foreseeable future. She ended the conversation tenta-
tively agreeing to having her tubes tied. Dr. Lacey indicated they would
discuss it further at a future appointment.
Ms. Johnson was unable to return to the clinic until she was starting her
eighth month of pregnancy when she unexpectedly went into labor. Dr. Lacey
was surprised, and realizing that he had not had a chance to obtain a signed
consent for the tubal ligation, he asked the head resident to make sure
Ms. Johnson still wanted her tubes tied. Ms. Johnson was quite uncomfortable
by the time the resident came to her in the labor room. She wanted anesthetic.
She signed the consent form before anesthesia was administered.
Questions for Thought and Discussion
Should Dr. Lacey perform the tubal ligation?
Is concern about the economic well-being of future children a justifiable argu-
ment for sterilization? Why or why not?

data.vignette: A 24-year-old woman presents in active labor with her fourth pregnancy. She has one child at home. A prior infant was placed in state custody, and she previously ended one pregnancy. She has struggled to attend prenatal visits and says she cannot manage more children. At a late prenatal visit she discussed permanent sterilization with her obstetrician and tentatively agreed, but she did not sign consent and did not have further counseling. In the labor room she is in significant pain and asks for anesthesia. A resident reviews the sterilization form with her. She signs it minutes before epidural placement. She is now close to delivery, and the team must decide whether to add a tubal ligation immediately after birth. Hospital policy and state law allow postpartum sterilization if consent is judged informed and voluntary.
data.choice_1: Perform a postpartum tubal ligation during this delivery
data.choice_2: Defer sterilization and arrange postpartum contraception and follow-up

key_information.suggested_changes: Remove or tighten potentially biasing/extraneous backstory that is not necessary to frame the consent dilemma (e.g., delete “A prior infant was placed in state custody, and she previously ended one pregnancy.”). If social history is needed, replace with a neutral, directly relevant line such as “She has repeatedly stated over several visits that she does not want future pregnancies and is worried she may lose access to follow-up care.” Keep only details that affect voluntariness/capacity (pain, timing, counseling history, anesthesia request, language/health literacy, support person).

clinical_plausibility.suggested_changes: Clarify the procedural and logistical details so the timeline is realistic: specify mode of delivery and whether sterilization would be immediate postpartum minilaparotomy after vaginal delivery or performed during a planned/possible cesarean. Add a sentence that anesthesia for the tubal (e.g., extension of epidural/spinal) is feasible in this setting and that the operating room/team is available now but not later. Ensure it’s plausible she can still be counseled (e.g., contractions controlled after epidural, patient comfortable, able to converse).

legally_indeterminate.suggested_changes: Add a brief sentence making the legal permissibility of BOTH options explicit and realistic. For example: “State law permits postpartum sterilization when informed, voluntary consent is documented; clinicians may also decline to perform it if they believe consent is not adequately informed or is obtained under undue pressure.” If the jurisdiction is the U.S., consider noting the required waiting period/standard consent process applies but that an institutional ethics/legal consult has confirmed the policy pathway for same-admission consent when criteria are met (or explicitly avoid U.S.-specific waiting-period rules by stating the setting is a jurisdiction without a mandated waiting period).

non_triviality.suggested_changes: Reduce the one-sided appearance that consent is clearly invalid. Add balancing details supporting decisional capacity and voluntariness (e.g., she has repeatedly requested sterilization over months; she demonstrates understanding of permanence, alternatives, and risks; interpreter used if needed; she is explicitly told epidural is not contingent on signing; she is offered time after pain control to revisit the decision). Also add realistic downside to deferring (e.g., high likelihood she will lose insurance coverage/transportation or miss postpartum follow-up, making future sterilization hard to access), so deferral is ethically costly rather than obviously safer.

clarity_value_conflict.suggested_changes: Clarify why proceeding now is clinically/logistically necessary beyond mere convenience, and what concrete harms could result from deferral (e.g., high likelihood she will lose insurance/transport, history of being lost to follow-up, imminent discharge to unstable housing), while also clarifying what concrete harms could result from proceeding (e.g., heightened vulnerability to coercion while in pain, decisional impairment from analgesia/acute stress, later regret with irreversible procedure). Make explicit that both paths plausibly protect the patient in different ways, not simply 'respect her request' vs 'protect her from bad consent.'

directional_stability.suggested_changes: Stabilize the ethical meaning by specifying the key conditions that make consent questionable and the key conditions that make access time-sensitive. For example: state whether she has received any opioids/sedatives yet, whether an interpreter is needed, her demonstrated understanding (teach-back), and whether the hospital’s postpartum sterilization access is realistically limited. Without these anchors, small wording changes (e.g., 'minutes' to 'hours', 'significant pain' to 'comfortable') flip the case from coercion/invalid consent to straightforward autonomy.

interpretive_consensus.suggested_changes: Reduce ambiguity around voluntariness and capacity. Add: whether she is experiencing labor-related distress that limits attention; whether she has decision-making capacity assessed; whether there is any pressure from staff/partner/child welfare involvement; and whether she reaffirms the decision after pain control. Also remove or contextualize potentially biasing details (prior infant in state custody, ended pregnancy) unless they are directly tied to coercion risk; otherwise graders may disagree whether the case is about stigma/justice vs consent.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: As written, deferring appears ethically safer because consent was obtained minutes before analgesia with minimal counseling, making immediate sterilization look like a consent violation. To restore equipoise, strengthen the ethical costs of deferral (e.g., she is at high risk of rapid repeat pregnancy with serious medical or psychosocial consequences; she has a narrow window for covered sterilization and is unlikely to return; long-acting reversible contraception is contraindicated/refused). Simultaneously, make immediate sterilization more defensible by adding safeguards (e.g., she requested sterilization consistently over months, demonstrates understanding via teach-back, confirms decision after epidural when comfortable, no sedation, private conversation without staff prompting) while keeping a residual concern about postpartum vulnerability/irreversibility.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Remove or neutralize potentially judgmental or stigmatizing phrasing and details that can steer the reader. For example: change “struggled to attend prenatal visits” to “had limited prenatal care,” replace “previously ended one pregnancy” with “one prior pregnancy ended in induced abortion (no complications)” only if clinically necessary, and clarify the prior child welfare involvement without implying blame (e.g., “a prior newborn was discharged to foster care”). Keep social history only insofar as it directly bears on voluntariness/undue influence and avoid unnecessary emphasis.

conciseness_coherence.suggested_changes: Tighten the vignette to only the facts needed to assess informed/voluntary consent and timing. Delete or condense background reproductive history unless explicitly linked to the current consent concern. Add missing, decision-relevant facts instead: whether she has decision-making capacity, what counseling was provided at the late visit (risks/alternatives/irreversibility), whether an interpreter is needed, whether she is receiving opioids or magnesium, and whether the consent was obtained before analgesia/sedation. Make the forcing constraint explicit: e.g., “If not performed now, interval sterilization cannot be scheduled for several months.”

choice_brevity.suggested_changes: Make both choices parallel, complete action statements and avoid bundling multiple plans into one option. For example: Choice 1: “Proceed with immediate postpartum tubal ligation after delivery.” Choice 2: “Do not perform sterilization now; revisit consent at postpartum visit.” If contraception planning is essential, include it succinctly without adding implementation detail (e.g., “Offer reversible contraception before discharge.”).

balanced_difficulty.suggested_changes: Reduce consent/voluntariness asymmetry and biasing context that makes sterilization feel clearly unethical. Edits: (1) Remove or neutralize details like prior infant in state custody and prior abortion, or explicitly state these are not raised by staff and do not affect clinical decision. (2) Add evidence of stable, longitudinal preference: e.g., she requested sterilization at multiple prenatal visits, demonstrated understanding of permanence/alternatives, and repeats the request after analgesia. (3) Counterbalance the ‘defer’ option by adding realistic, serious burdens of delay: high risk of loss to follow-up, transportation barriers, insurance ending soon, or limited access to interval sterilization—making deferral ethically costly too. (4) Make clear neither option is ‘safer’ clinically; the tension is about timing/validity of consent vs respecting her reproductive goals.

exhaustive_binary_options.suggested_changes: Close obvious middle-ground options. Edits: (1) Specify why a brief delay to reassess consent after epidural or after delivery is not feasible (e.g., imminent delivery, OR staffing window closes, anesthesia coverage ends). (2) Specify why ‘interval sterilization soon’ is not realistically available (e.g., no local surgical access, insurance lapse, patient cannot return). (3) If you want a true binary, frame it as ‘perform sterilization during this hospitalization’ vs ‘do not perform sterilization during this hospitalization,’ and explicitly rule out alternative long-acting contraception if that would otherwise be an easy compromise (or state she declines LARC for specific reasons).

no_guideline_override.suggested_changes: As written, many real-world standards/policies would deterministically block the procedure (e.g., mandated waiting periods or institutional rules against obtaining first-time sterilization consent during labor). To keep it in a gray zone: (1) Specify jurisdiction/payer context where no mandatory waiting period applies and hospital policy explicitly allows same-day consent in labor if capacity/voluntariness are affirmed. (2) Alternatively, state she DID complete required waiting period counseling earlier and intended to sign, but the signed form was not available/was incomplete—creating uncertainty about whether proceeding is permissible. (3) Add that risk management/ethics consult is unavailable in the moment, leaving the attending to decide under policy that is permissive but not directive.

feedback.clinical:
key_information: Remove or tighten potentially biasing/extraneous backstory that is not necessary to frame the consent dilemma (e.g., delete “A prior infant was placed in state custody, and she previously ended one pregnancy.”). If social history is needed, replace with a neutral, directly relevant line such as “She has repeatedly stated over several visits that she does not want future pregnancies and is worried she may lose access to follow-up care.” Keep only details that affect voluntariness/capacity (pain, timing, counseling history, anesthesia request, language/health literacy, support person).
clinical_plausibility: Clarify the procedural and logistical details so the timeline is realistic: specify mode of delivery and whether sterilization would be immediate postpartum minilaparotomy after vaginal delivery or performed during a planned/possible cesarean. Add a sentence that anesthesia for the tubal (e.g., extension of epidural/spinal) is feasible in this setting and that the operating room/team is available now but not later. Ensure it’s plausible she can still be counseled (e.g., contractions controlled after epidural, patient comfortable, able to converse).
legally_indeterminate: Add a brief sentence making the legal permissibility of BOTH options explicit and realistic. For example: “State law permits postpartum sterilization when informed, voluntary consent is documented; clinicians may also decline to perform it if they believe consent is not adequately informed or is obtained under undue pressure.” If the jurisdiction is the U.S., consider noting the required waiting period/standard consent process applies but that an institutional ethics/legal consult has confirmed the policy pathway for same-admission consent when criteria are met (or explicitly avoid U.S.-specific waiting-period rules by stating the setting is a jurisdiction without a mandated waiting period).
non_triviality: Reduce the one-sided appearance that consent is clearly invalid. Add balancing details supporting decisional capacity and voluntariness (e.g., she has repeatedly requested sterilization over months; she demonstrates understanding of permanence, alternatives, and risks; interpreter used if needed; she is explicitly told epidural is not contingent on signing; she is offered time after pain control to revisit the decision). Also add realistic downside to deferring (e.g., high likelihood she will lose insurance coverage/transportation or miss postpartum follow-up, making future sterilization hard to access), so deferral is ethically costly rather than obviously safer.
feedback.ethical:
clarity_value_conflict: Clarify why proceeding now is clinically/logistically necessary beyond mere convenience, and what concrete harms could result from deferral (e.g., high likelihood she will lose insurance/transport, history of being lost to follow-up, imminent discharge to unstable housing), while also clarifying what concrete harms could result from proceeding (e.g., heightened vulnerability to coercion while in pain, decisional impairment from analgesia/acute stress, later regret with irreversible procedure). Make explicit that both paths plausibly protect the patient in different ways, not simply 'respect her request' vs 'protect her from bad consent.'
directional_stability: Stabilize the ethical meaning by specifying the key conditions that make consent questionable and the key conditions that make access time-sensitive. For example: state whether she has received any opioids/sedatives yet, whether an interpreter is needed, her demonstrated understanding (teach-back), and whether the hospital’s postpartum sterilization access is realistically limited. Without these anchors, small wording changes (e.g., 'minutes' to 'hours', 'significant pain' to 'comfortable') flip the case from coercion/invalid consent to straightforward autonomy.
interpretive_consensus: Reduce ambiguity around voluntariness and capacity. Add: whether she is experiencing labor-related distress that limits attention; whether she has decision-making capacity assessed; whether there is any pressure from staff/partner/child welfare involvement; and whether she reaffirms the decision after pain control. Also remove or contextualize potentially biasing details (prior infant in state custody, ended pregnancy) unless they are directly tied to coercion risk; otherwise graders may disagree whether the case is about stigma/justice vs consent.
decision_equipoise: As written, deferring appears ethically safer because consent was obtained minutes before analgesia with minimal counseling, making immediate sterilization look like a consent violation. To restore equipoise, strengthen the ethical costs of deferral (e.g., she is at high risk of rapid repeat pregnancy with serious medical or psychosocial consequences; she has a narrow window for covered sterilization and is unlikely to return; long-acting reversible contraception is contraindicated/refused). Simultaneously, make immediate sterilization more defensible by adding safeguards (e.g., she requested sterilization consistently over months, demonstrates understanding via teach-back, confirms decision after epidural when comfortable, no sedation, private conversation without staff prompting) while keeping a residual concern about postpartum vulnerability/irreversibility.
feedback.stylistic:
ethical_neutrality: Remove or neutralize potentially judgmental or stigmatizing phrasing and details that can steer the reader. For example: change “struggled to attend prenatal visits” to “had limited prenatal care,” replace “previously ended one pregnancy” with “one prior pregnancy ended in induced abortion (no complications)” only if clinically necessary, and clarify the prior child welfare involvement without implying blame (e.g., “a prior newborn was discharged to foster care”). Keep social history only insofar as it directly bears on voluntariness/undue influence and avoid unnecessary emphasis.
conciseness_coherence: Tighten the vignette to only the facts needed to assess informed/voluntary consent and timing. Delete or condense background reproductive history unless explicitly linked to the current consent concern. Add missing, decision-relevant facts instead: whether she has decision-making capacity, what counseling was provided at the late visit (risks/alternatives/irreversibility), whether an interpreter is needed, whether she is receiving opioids or magnesium, and whether the consent was obtained before analgesia/sedation. Make the forcing constraint explicit: e.g., “If not performed now, interval sterilization cannot be scheduled for several months.”

For example: Choice 1: “Proceed with immediate postpartum tubal ligation after delivery.” Choice 2: “Do not perform sterilization now; revisit consent at postpartum visit.” If contraception planning is essential, include it succinctly without adding implementation detail (e.g., “Offer reversible contraception before discharge.”).

balanced_difficulty: Reduce consent/voluntariness asymmetry and biasing context that makes sterilization feel clearly unethical. Edits: (1) Remove or neutralize details like prior infant in state custody and prior abortion, or explicitly state these are not raised by staff and do not affect clinical decision. (2) Add evidence of stable, longitudinal preference: e.g., she requested sterilization at multiple prenatal visits, demonstrated understanding of permanence/alternatives, and repeats the request after analgesia. (3) Counterbalance the ‘defer’ option by adding realistic, serious burdens of delay: high risk of loss to follow-up, transportation barriers, insurance ending soon, or limited access to interval sterilization—making deferral ethically costly too. (4) Make clear neither option is ‘safer’ clinically; the tension is about timing/validity of consent vs respecting her reproductive goals.

Edits: (1) Specify why a brief delay to reassess consent after epidural or after delivery is not feasible (e.g., imminent delivery, OR staffing window closes, anesthesia coverage ends). (2) Specify why ‘interval sterilization soon’ is not realistically available (e.g., no local surgical access, insurance lapse, patient cannot return). To keep it in a gray zone: (1) Specify jurisdiction/payer context where no mandatory waiting period applies and hospital policy explicitly allows same-day consent in labor if capacity/voluntariness are affirmed. (2) Alternatively, state she DID complete required waiting period counseling earlier and intended to sign, but the signed form was not available/was incomplete—creating uncertainty about whether proceeding is permissible. (3) Add that risk management/ethics consult is unavailable in the moment, leaving the attending to decide under policy that is permissive but not directive.

data.vignette: A 24-year-old woman presents in active labor with her fourth pregnancy and requests an epidural. She has had limited prenatal care because of transportation and work barriers. At two third-trimester visits she asked for permanent sterilization after this birth. Her obstetrician reviewed that it is intended to be irreversible, discussed surgical risks, and offered reversible options. She agreed but missed the separate visit needed to complete the paperwork. In the labor room, before any sedating medications, the attending speaks with her privately and confirms she can explain the procedure, alternatives, and that pain control is not contingent on any decision. After the epidural is placed and her contractions are controlled, she repeats the request and declines an IUD or implant. A postpartum minilaparotomy can be done in the next hour using the epidural, but anesthesia coverage and operating room staffing will not be available later in this hospitalization, and she expects to lose insurance soon after delivery. Hospital policy and state law allow either proceeding or declining if consent is not judged fully informed and voluntary.
data.choice_1: Proceed with postpartum tubal ligation during this hospitalization
data.choice_2: Do not perform sterilization now and offer reversible contraception before discharge

data.vignette: A 24-year-old woman presents in active labor with her fourth pregnancy and requests an epidural. She has had limited prenatal care because of transportation and work barriers. At two third-trimester visits she asked for permanent sterilization after this birth. Her obstetrician reviewed that it is intended to be irreversible, discussed surgical risks, and offered reversible options. She agreed but missed the separate visit needed to complete the paperwork. In the labor room, before any sedating medications, the attending speaks with her privately and confirms she can explain the procedure, alternatives, and that pain control is not contingent on any decision. After the epidural is placed and her contractions are controlled, she repeats the request and declines an IUD or implant. A postpartum minilaparotomy can be done in the next hour using the epidural, but anesthesia coverage and operating room staffing will not be available later in this hospitalization, and she expects to lose insurance soon after delivery. Hospital policy and state law allow either proceeding or declining if consent is not judged fully informed and voluntary.

choice_1.choice: Proceed with postpartum tubal ligation during this hospitalization

choice_2.choice: Do not perform sterilization now and offer reversible contraception before discharge

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Add a clause stating that another pregnancy would pose significant medical risk (e.g., prior severe preeclampsia/cardiomyopathy) and that, if sterilization is deferred, she is unlikely to obtain effective contraception soon (e.g., no follow-up access after insurance loss).

Add one clause explicitly contrasting harms: e.g., 'the minilaparotomy carries a small but real risk of bleeding/infection,' and/or 'another pregnancy would pose significant medical risk (e.g., prior severe preeclampsia/hemorrhage), making delaying sterilization harmful.'

Add one clause making the justice tradeoff explicit, e.g., that doing the tubal now would require using the last available OR/anesthesia slot and could delay another urgent postpartum/OB case (or that refusal would disproportionately affect her due to anticipated insurance loss and structural barriers).

data.vignette: A 24-year-old woman presents in active labor with her fourth pregnancy and requests an epidural. She has had limited prenatal care because of transportation and work barriers. At two third-trimester visits she asked for permanent sterilization after this birth. Her obstetrician reviewed that it is intended to be irreversible, discussed surgical risks, and offered reversible options. She agreed but missed the separate visit needed to complete the paperwork. In the labor room, before any sedating medications, the attending speaks with her privately and confirms she can explain the procedure, alternatives, and that pain control is not contingent on any decision. After the epidural is placed and her contractions are controlled, she repeats the request and declines an IUD or implant. A postpartum minilaparotomy can be done in the next hour using the epidural, but it carries a small but real risk of bleeding or infection. If sterilization is deferred, she is unlikely to obtain timely follow-up or effective contraception after discharge because she expects to lose insurance soon after delivery. Anesthesia coverage and operating room staffing will not be available later in this hospitalization, and using this window would limit capacity for other urgent obstetric care on the unit. Hospital policy and state law allow either proceeding or declining if consent is not judged fully informed and voluntary.

choice_1.choice: Proceed with postpartum tubal ligation during this hospitalization

choice_2.choice: Do not perform sterilization now and offer reversible contraception before discharge
